subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: international quikscript
msgSnippet: ... If there was spelling chaos as you suggest, then unless the people were writing words in ways that clearly did not do justice to their pronunciation, then
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
> pgabhart scripsit:
>


If there was spelling chaos as you suggest, then unless the people were
writing words in ways that clearly did not do justice to their
pronunciation, then the system in place, i.e. the Roman alphabet, had
problems representing English of that day. For instance, there were at
that time only five vowels in the alphabet. I suspect even then that
there were many more than five vowels in use. Plenty of opportunity for
ambiguity to abound it would seem to me.
>
>
> Actually, TO reflects a pretty reasonable spelling system for its time.
> A great deal has changed in spoken English since then, including
> the proliferation of regional accents (as distinct from English
> local dialects). For example, we spell "meet" and "meat" differently
> because they were actually pronounced differently in Shakespeare's day:
> "meet" much as today, but "meat" with a vowel like that of "met", but
> more prolonged: mehhhht. Most of those words eventually shifted to the
> FLEECE vowel, but "great" shifted to the FACE vowel instead, causing an
> irregularity where there was none before.
>
> The regional accent of Norfolk in England (as well as a few pockets
> elsewhere) still makes the ancient distinctions between "pail" and "pale",
> between "meat" and "meet", and between "toe" and "tow". Similarly, a much
> larger area (Scotland, Ireland, parts of the Caribbean, and parts of the
> Southern U.S. and New England among older speakers) still pronounce "for"
> and "fore" differently, and do not rhyme "pork" and "fork". In all these
> cases, the exact details of the pronunciation aren't the same everywhere;
> it's the fact that the distinctions are still being made that counts.
>
















And I still make such a distinction myself although I do not feel I have
a particularly southern U.S. accent.

I should also note that I was focused on Dutch orthography and am aware
there is not a Dutch government.

>
> > The bare statement that the official Dutch orthography changes every
> few
> > decades implies that some organization with authority makes that
> > change. What is that organization? The Dutch government? A language
> > academy? It appears to me that standardized does mean "fixed" in
> > English because there is no authority to force a change on a language
> > spoken around the world.
>
> It sometimes goes bottom-up, sometimes top-down, and sometimes
> an orthography is created long before the governments
> (of the Netherlands and Belgium) actually adopt it: some
> orthographies were used only in one of the two countries.
> See http://en.wikipedia/wiki/History_of_Dutch_orthography
> <http://en.wikipedia/wiki/History_of_Dutch_orthography> for details.
>
>
>
